turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Pseudorhabdosynochus firmicoleatus.
turn.1: What is the difference between Pseudorhabdosynochus firmicoleatus and other types of fish parasites?
turn.2: Pseudorhabdosynochus firmicoleatus Pseudorhabdosynochus firmicoleatus is a diplectanid monogenean parasite on the gills of the Yellowedge grouper, "Epinephelus flavolimbatus" and the Snowy grouper, "Epinephelus niveatus".
turn.3: What year was this species of fish parasites discovered?
turn.4: It was described by Kritsky, Bakenhaster and Adams in 2015.
turn.5: How big are the fish parasites?
turn.6: "Pseudorhabdosynochus firmicoleatus" is a small monogenean, 400-500 µm in length.
turn.7: What other characteristics are there about the fish parasites that you can tell me?
turn.8: The species has the general characteristics of other species of "Pseudorhabdosynochus", with a flat body and a posterior haptor, which is the organ by which the monogenean attaches itself to the gill of is host.
turn.9: Do the fish parasites sting the fish when they attach themselves to the gills?
turn.10: The haptor bears two squamodiscs, one ventral and one dorsal.
turn.11: Are the fish parasites male or female?
turn.12: The sclerotized male copulatory organ, or "quadriloculate organ", has the shape of a bean with four internal chambers, as in other species of "Pseudorhabdosynochus".
